Project Number: 42125 
Regional Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA)  
October 2008 
Capacity Building for Regional Trade Integration and 
Facilitation
(Financed by the Japan Special Fund)

ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION

(R-CDTA)

Head        J. W. Lee, Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) 
Director       S. Madhur, OREI  
Team leader      G. Wignaraja, Principal Economist, OREI   
Team members     S. Hamanaka, Economist, OREI 
        J. W. Kang, Economist, OREI  
W. Paz, Senior Economics Officer, OREI

1
I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.   The regional cooperation and integration strategy adopted by the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) in 2006 identified trade and investment as one of its four pillars (pillar 2). The 
strategy provides the basis for ADB’s capacity building initiatives in the area of regional trade. 
Trade policy capacity varies significantly across Asia and the Pacific, with some (e.g., the South 
Asian economies) lacking the skills needed to take advantage of new opportunities created by 
global  and  regional  integration.  ADB’s  regional  departments  and  the  Office  of  Regional 
Economic  Integration  (OREI)  are  engaged  in  various  capacity  building  activities  for  ADB’s 
developing member countries (DMCs). This technical assistance (TA)1 seeks to strengthen 
ADB’s existing efforts at the regional level to enhance the capacity of DMCs to trade effectively 
and efficiently. Broad-based participation through stronger public–private partnership (PPP) and 
effective coordination with other trade-related projects in the region are crucial to adopting an 
integrated and pragmatic regional approach to trade. The TA will therefore be implemented in 
partnership with global (e.g., the World Trade Organization [WTO]) and regional institutions 
(such  as  the  United  Nations  Economic  and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific 
[UNESCAP], Association of Southeast Asian Nations [ASEAN], and South Asian Association for 
Regional  Cooperation  [SAARC]).  The  TA  deals  with  four  interrelated  components.  These 
include capacity building in the broad sense through the Aid for Trade (AFT) Road Map, support 
for regional trade facilitation, training courses on free trade agreements (FTAs), and support for 
subregional trade integration.2
II.  ISSUES 
2.  ADB has actively supported trade integration and facilitation through the years as a 
means to increase investment and trade, and, ultimately, to reduce poverty in the region. ADB’s 
experience includes conducting several training courses;3 a manual on designing, negotiating, 
and implementing FTAs;4 support for subregional integration in East Asia (e.g., capacity building 
for the ASEAN Secretariat);5 a number of subregional initiatives on trade facilitation through the 
Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) and the Greater Mekong Subregion 
(GMS) Programs; and a high-level AFT conference in September 2007 in Manila6 that reviewed 
the trade capacity building needs and discussed the necessity for increased AFT resources for 
the Asia and the Pacific region. These experiences bode well in the medium term for developing 
DMCs’ capacity to take advantage of regional and global trading opportunities.  
3. Need  to  Address  Trade-Related  Constraints.  Trade-related constraints are widely 
acknowledged at both the national and regional levels,7 although issues have not been dealt 
with via a pragmatic regional approach. Consensus is needed to effectively use developmental 
aid interventions in trade-related activities for boosting trade capacities, and particularly for the

2
least developed countries and small states. Institutional support for international trade is also 
crucial to minimizing the costs from distorting trade policies and procedures. 
4. Need to Increase Support for Regional Trade Facilitation. Trade facilitation requires 
adopting efficient and transparent methods to facilitate the trade in goods. At the national level, 
individual countries have implemented measures to improve trade, but a recent study has 
indicated that, individually, countries cannot fully realize the benefits from trade facilitation 
programs.8 The  study  reemphasizes  the  need  for  a  regional  approach  to  trade-facilitating 
reforms. ADB and other regional institutions in Asia, such as UNESCAP, have initiated hard9
and soft10 infrastructure activities to enhance trade flows in the region. But Asia and the Pacific 
still lack a central regional venue, similar to the World Economic Forum, that would regularly 
bring together global and regional partners, as well as public–private stakeholders, to discuss 
trade  facilitation  issues.  Equally  important  is  to  promote  knowledge  development  and 
dissemination of best practice on trade facilitation so that DMCs and stakeholders will have a 
better, practical appreciation of trade facilitation reforms. 
5. Need to Enhance Public–Private Partnerships in Trade-Related Activities. The role 
of the private sector is important in enhancing trade integration and facilitating trade. Many of 
the investments needed to develop DMC trading capacities are best undertaken through PPPs 
to take advantage of the synergy of government and the business sector.11
6. Need to Increase Capacity of Trade Officials. The Asia and Pacific region has a 
plethora of FTAs, and the limited capacity of DMC officials is overstretched. Recognizing this 
constraint, ADB organized several FTA training courses between 2006 and 2008.12 With the 
proliferation of new-style comprehensive FTAs in the region, there is also a continuing need to 
provide DMCs capacity building to ensure a sustainable pool of qualified trade officials. 
7. Need to Initiate Stronger Support for Deeper Subregional Trade Integration. ADB 
supports nurturing a multi-track and multi-speed approach to regional integration for Asia’s 
various  subregions  (including  South  Asia,  the  Pacific,  Central  Asia,  and  the  GMS)  with 
interventions for specific needs to permit participation in integration processes. For instance, 
many of the FTAs in South Asia, Central Asia, and the Pacific states are still characterized by 
small product coverage and narrow preference margins. To realize the FTAs’ full potential for 
increasing the Asian subregions’ market access, it is necessary to deepen regional integration 
(beyond just trade in goods). Capacity building and technical support to various subregional 
entities (e.g., the SAARC Secretariat) can assist in this integration.
8.  Building upon ADB’s experience and partnership with global and regional development 
institutions, this project aims to provide continuous technical assistance and capacity building in 
order to sustain and deepen the integration and trade facilitation efforts of DMCs in the region.

3
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA’s impact will be expansion of trade and investment in Asia and the Pacific 
through an integrated and pragmatic regional approach. Capacity building will enable DMCs to 
maximize the benefits of trade policy and facilitation initiatives in the region. The envisaged 
outcomes are more awareness of trade-related needs and an effective approach to closing 
regional gaps through AFT; a regional approach and strengthened PPPs in trade facilitation; 
and enhanced institutional capacity of DMCs for dealing with FTAs and deepening subregional 
trade integration.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The  TA  will  assist  DMCs  in  improving  trade  policy  formation  and  strengthening 
institutional capacity for trade facilitation and integration. This will include four main components:   
11. Component 1: Aid for Trade Road Map for Asia and the Pacific. This will define 
regional trade-related constraints and design an effective regional AFT approach. As agreed 
during the first AFT Review in Manila (chaired by ADB President Haruhiko Kuroda and WTO 
Director-General Pascal Lamy in September 2007, and as reported by the Managing Director-
General to the Global AFT Review in Geneva in November 2007) future steps in the regional 
AFT agenda include the following: 
(i)  The Regional Technical Group on Aid for Trade for Asia and the Pacific (to 
convene  in  late  2008),  consisting  of  senior  technical-level  representatives  of 
recipient countries, bilateral donors, and regional and multilateral institutions. 
ADB will be a member of the regional technical group and coordinate its work. 
The technical working group will meet at least twice (once in Manila and again in 
Geneva) during 2008–2010. 
(ii)  The Proposal for Aid for Trade in Asia and the Pacific. A succinct, regional 
proposal will be crafted by the regional technical group to provide a practical 
framework  for  operationalizing  AFT  in  the  region.  It  is  envisaged  that  the 
proposal will synthesize specific AFT needs, objectives, activities, and actors; it 
will include an implementation schedule, define financing needs, and structure a 
monitoring framework based on the Paris Principles. The draft proposal will be 
circulated for comments to relevant stakeholders and presented at regional and 
international forums.
(iii)  The  Study  on  Trade  Performance  and  Aid  for  Trade  in  Asia-Pacific.  A 
complement to the proposal, this planned knowledge product in 2009 will analyze 
trade performance among countries representing the diversity of Asia and the 
Pacific.  The  study’s  findings  are  expected  to  be  disseminated  as  widely  as 
possible through various websites and conferences. 
12. Component  2:  Support  for  Regional  Trade Facilitation.  This component aims to 
promote adopting effective regional trade facilitation measures, strengthen trade facilitation 
initiatives through strong PPPs, and enhance trade facilitation capacity. The TA envisages two 
activities: publication of a trade facilitation manual (2009–2010), and a high-level conference in 
2009 to promote eventual formation of a regional trade facilitation forum. This will complement 
ADB’s and UNESCAP’s ongoing regional and subregional trade facilitation initiatives (e.g., the

4
CAREC  and  GMS  trade  facilitation  programs).13 The  component  will  be  implemented  in 
collaboration  with  UNESCAP14 and  coordination  with  regional  departments  (and  especially 
those with subregional trade facilitation programs).  
13.  A manual on trade facilitation will be developed that will draw on ADB’s expertise and 
technical reports on trade facilitation, UNESCAP’s trade facilitation handbooks,15 and ADB’s 
FTA  manual.16 The  manual  on  trade  facilitation  is  envisaged  to  include  (i)  a  conceptual 
framework on trade facilitation (which will provide a definition of trade facilitation); (ii) indicators 
for  assessing  customs  needs  and  behind-the-border  issues  on  logistics,  quarantine,  and 
standards; and (iii) case studies that will highlight best practice in implementing trade facilitation 
initiatives  (including  the  ASEAN  single-window,  GMS  cross-border  agreements,  customs 
modernization, trade finance facilitation program, and PPPs). A dissemination plan will be drawn 
up to include posting on ADB and UNESCAP websites plus regional and in-country launch 
exercises.  
14.  A high-level regional conference on trade facilitation will be conducted in 2009 to provide 
a venue for sharing best-practice experiences in trade facilitation initiatives, as well as to assist 
in bringing regional players together and promoting PPPs in trade facilitation. The conference 
will be organized in collaboration with such global and regional partners as the WTO, World 
Customs Organization (WCO), and UNESCAP. The conference may become a regular event.17
15. Component  3:  Training  Courses  on  Designing,  Negotiating,  and  Implementing 
FTAs. Two regional training courses, with participants from all subregions in Asia and the 
Pacific, will be conducted during 2009–2010.18 The courses aim to enhance the technical and 
analytical skills of DMC trade officials involved in FTAs and equip them with the necessary 
tools for undertaking FTAs, such as (i) background concepts and trends, (ii) designing best 
practice FTAs, and (iii) strategizing FTA negotiation and implementation. The training courses 
will build upon ADB’s FTA training programs.19 The FTA manual (footnote 16) as well as the 
envisaged trade facilitation manual will be used as part of the core course materials. New trade 
issues (e.g., WTO-plus provisions on trade facilitation and cooperation enhancement) will be 
dealt with extensively. The courses will involve a mix of formal presentations, case studies, 
group  work,  discussions  on  trends  among  FTAs  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific,  and  simulation

5
exercises. There will be practical group exercises on using ADB’s FTA and trade indicators 
databases (www.aric.adb.org), as well as simulated trade negotiations. OREI will manage the 
training courses. Training will be conducted by international experts and experienced FTA 
negotiators, experts from international (e.g., WTO) and regional entities (e.g., ASEAN and 
SAARC), and ADBI and ADB staff (OREI and regional departments).  
16. Component  4:  Support  for  Deepening  Subregional  Trade  Integration.  This
component aims to provide capacity building for extending the scope of subregional FTAs (such 
as the South Asia Free Trade Agreement and the Pacific Island Countries Trade Agreement) 
into  such  new  areas  as  services  and  investment.  This  type  of  TA  has  been  specifically 
requested by the SAARC and the Indian Government during an ADB consultation mission to 
New Delhi, India on 5 and 7 March 2008 and in consultations between ADB staff and a SAARC 
Secretariat official.20 Leveraging on ADB’s completed and ongoing research activities,21 and in 
close consultation with Asian DMCs, a study on new issues22 in FTAs in Asia and the Pacific23
will be carried out in 2009 and widely disseminated through the ADB website and a workshop in 
2010. A workshop may also be held with various regional secretariats on how to implement 
liberalization in such new areas as services, investment, and intellectual property rights, as well 
as regarding other integration initiatives.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $900,000 and will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan 
Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. It will cover remuneration, travel, and per 
diems  for  international  and  national  consultants  and  resource  persons;  conference-related 
expenditures; travel costs for participants; other training expenditures; publication of the trade 
facilitation manual, studies, and reports; equipment rentals; and miscellaneous expenses. A 
detailed cost breakdown and proposed financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA. OREI will administer and implement the 
TA with support from the regional departments. DMCs will be consulted on the priority topics for 
the  studies,  FTA  training,  and  workshops.  ADB,  WTO,  donor  agencies,  and  regional 
development  partners  will  collaborate  under  component  1.  ADB  will  work  closely  with 
UNESCAP  and  the  WCO  in  activities  under  component  2.  An  annex  to  the  existing 
memorandum  of  understanding  with  UNESCAP  will  be  prepared  defining  the  roles  and 
responsibilities of ADB and UNESCAP in implementing component 2. ADB will coordinate with 
regional  organizations  (e.g.,  ASEAN  and  SAARC)  in  implementing  component  3  and  with 
subregional entities (such as SAARC and the Pacific Island Forum states) for component 4.  
19.  The TA will require approximately 5 person-months of international and 20 person-
months of national consulting services. In addition, it will require 1.5 person-months (combined)

of international resource persons for a high-level conference on trade facilitation and the FTA 
training courses. The national consultant for the TA (trade specialist and/or capacity building 
coordinator) will be based at ADB headquarters and will assist in the overall implementation. 
ADB will engage the consultants on an individual basis and in accordance with its Guidelines on 
the  Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  other  arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for engaging consultants. An outline of the terms of reference for the 
consultants and resource persons is in Appendix 3. 
20.  The TA is expected to run for 36 months, from November 2008 to November 2011. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis for Capacity Building for Regional Trade Integration and Facilitation, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE 
A.  International Consultants 
1. Trade Economist for the Aid for Trade (AFT) Proposal and Research Study (1.5 
person-months)
1.  The trade economist will have a postgraduate-level background in international trade, 
macroeconomics, or economics; in-depth expertise in international trade policies and regional 
economic cooperation; plus substantial knowledge of current developments in the World Trade 
Organization’s Aid for Trade initiative as well as the World Trade Organization and Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)’s  Road  Map  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific.  Based  on  the  document 
Mobilizing  Aid  for  Trade:  Focus  Asia  and  the  Pacific  Report  and  Recommendations,1 the 
purpose of the assignment is to provide inputs for the regional technical group in crafting the 
proposal for AFT in Asia and the Pacific and, as a complement to the proposal, to prepare a 
study on trade performance and AFT. The goal of the study is to analyze and define lessons 
learned  about  what  has  made  trade-related  development  assistance  work  for  successful 
economies in the region. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the consultant will 
(i)  prepare a detailed outline for the Study on Trade Performance and Aid for Trade 
in Asia-Pacific;   
(ii)  prepare the paper based on the outline approved by ADB;  
(iii)  contribute to the research needs of the AFT Technical Working Group for Asia 
and the Pacific, including inputs to prepare the proposal for the AFT for Asia and 
the Pacific;  
(iv)  revise the proposal and study following ADB’s review; and 
(v)  undertake consultations with stakeholders and make presentations at events, as 
required.
2.  Customs, Trade Logistics, Transport, and Transit Experts (1.5 person-months, 
combined)
2.  The experts will have proven practical expertise in customs, trade logistics, transport, 
and transit, as well as experience in facilitating regional trade in Asia-Pacific. They will be 
responsible for drafting the chapters based on the outline prepared by ADB and UNESCAP. The 
experts will prepare inputs to the trade facilitation manual. It is envisaged that the manual will 
include (i) a conceptual framework for trade facilitation, (ii) measurement of trade facilitation, 
and (iii) implementation of trade facilitation. Reporting to ADB and UNESCAP, the consultant 
will
(i)  write one or two main chapters or sections and case studies of the manual, as 
may be assigned, from the outline approved by ADB and UNESCAP; and 
(ii)  revise the contents of the manual as required.  
3. Trade Economist for Subregional Trade Integration (2.0 person-months) 
3.   The trade economist will have a postgraduate-level background in international trade, 
macroeconomics, or public policy; in-depth expertise in international trade policies and regional 
economic cooperation; and substantial knowledge of Asian subregional FTAs. The assignment 
                                                
1  ADB and WTO. 2007. Mobilizing Aid for Trade: Focus Asia and the Pacific Report and Recommendations. Manila.

12
is to prepare a study and training materials for new issues in FTAs. Under the direct supervision 
of ADB, the consultant will   
(i)  prepare an outline of the study on new issues on integration (i.e., relating to 
services,  investments,  intellectual  property  rights,  and  competition  policy)  in 
consultation with member countries of subregional FTAs in Asia and the Pacific 
and ADB staff,
(ii)  conduct a research study on new areas in FTAs and contribute relevant training 
materials, 
(iii)  make presentations at workshops and training events as needed, and  
(iv)   revise the paper based on comments from ADB.  
B.  International Resource Persons (1.5 person-months, combined) 
4.   The  TA  will  require  the  services  of  a  pool  of  regional  resource  persons  to  make 
presentations at FTA training courses and a high-level conference on trade facilitation. The 
consultants  will  have  substantial  knowledge  in  the  areas  of  World  Trade  Organization 
economics and/or law, as well as regional free trade agreements. They will have expertise in 
specific areas, such as trade in goods or services, investment, intellectual property rights, 
dispute settlement, and trade facilitation. The resource persons can be from the public sector, 
private sector, and international organizations. The resource persons will 
(i)   make  presentations  and  provide  training  materials  for  training  course  or 
workshop participants on the topics assigned to them; and  
(ii)  moderate and facilitate active discussion and exchanges of ideas among the 
participants, as well as with other resource persons. 
C.   National Consultant 
5. Trade  Specialist  and/or  Capacity  Building  Coordinator (20 person-months). The 
consultant  should  have  a  post-graduate  degree  in  economics,  law,  public  policy  or  the 
equivalent, and he or she shall have substantial experience in the area of international trade. 
Excellent coordination and communication skills are required. The consultant will work at ADB 
headquarters during TA implementation. Under the direct supervision of ADB, the consultant will 
(i)  provide technical assistance for ADB research studies on trade integration and 
trade facilitation; 
(ii)  support the preparation of research studies on AFT, subregional trade integration, 
and trade facilitation; 
(iii)  provide  technical  support  to  both  international  consultants  and  ADB  staff  in 
implementing  the  TA,  including  to  organize  FTA  training  courses,  seminars, 
workshops, and conferences as needed;  
(iv)  undertake quantitative analysis as required; and  
(v)  perform other tasks as may be assigned by ADB staff.
